DOC.brief_summary: Age-Related Macular Degeneration (AMD) is a degenerative eye disease of the retina that causes a progressive loss of central vision. AMD is the leading cause of legal blindness among adults age 50 or older in the Western world. AMD presents in two different types - "dry" and the more severe "wet" form. Wet AMD is caused by the growth of abnormal blood vessels in the macula. Squalamine lactate is an investigational drug that may prevent the growth of these abnormal blood vessels. This study will test the safety and efficacy of Squalamine in the treatment of AMD.
DOC.brief_title: A Safety and Efficacy Study of MSI-1256F (Squalamine Lactate) To Treat "Wet" Age-Related Macular Degeneration
DOC.criteria: Patients with a diagnosis of "wet" agerelated macular degeneration Prior treatment of "wet" agerelated macular degeneration in the affected eye in the past 3 months
